Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation2: The mentor arranged a short meeting in an otherwise packed day.
Story: I glanced at my phone, heart pounding. My stepdad had just texted, “Rough day. Can we talk?” I knew he’d been struggling lately, and Mom always said I was the one who could get through to him. I wanted to be there, to ask if he was okay, to listen like I always did. But at the same time, my mentor’s email notification popped up: “Can you meet in 10 minutes? I only have a short window today.” She was always so busy, and I’d been waiting weeks for this chance to ask her about my project. I felt torn—my family needed me, but so did my future. If I ignored my stepdad, I’d feel guilty for not being the support he counted on. If I missed my mentor, I might not get another chance soon, and I didn’t want to seem ungrateful or unreliable. My hands shook as I stared at both messages, feeling the weight of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
